results:
Based on the search results, I found some information about Maria Skibniewska's Polish translation of Tolkien's works, though specific details about her interpretation of the ring in "The Hobbit" are limited. Here's what I found:

## Maria Skibniewska's Polish Translations of Tolkien

Maria Skibniewska first translated "The Hobbit," which was published in Polish in 1960 by Iskry Publishers.(no content)She signed the contract for the translation of "The Lord of the Rings" with Czytelnik in 1958.

### Translation Work and Process

In June 1959, she wrote a letter to Allen & Unwin, asking for guidance to assist her with the translation, which was forwarded to Tolkien.(no content)It wasn't until after reminders from Czytelnik that he provided some general advice, which was sent to Skibniewska.(no content)There is no evidence of any direct correspondence between the author and the Polish translator, but it is possible that her letter, forwarded to Tolkien, is preserved in his archives at the Bodleian Library.

### Quality and Reception

Skibniewska's translations are regarded as faithful to the original and well-capturing the style and language of the author, although they are not without certain errors.(no content)Conversely, Skibniewska's translation of The Lord of the Rings is considered excellent or even nearly congruent, capturing Tolkien's elevated tone while maintaining his fluent style, making it very readable. It is regarded as the best available translation, often described as the most beautiful.(no content)Skibniewska's work is viewed as the canonical version of the novel in Polish.(no content)Although opinions were divided, the larger group of readers praised Skibniewska's translation and it was widely recognized as the canon.

### Notable Translation Choices

It was during her work on The Lord of the Rings when Skibniewska introduced into the Polish language such terms as "Śródziemie" ("Middle-earth") and "krasnoludowie" ("dwarves"), the latter being an augmentative form of the previously used "krasnoludki" ("dwarfs").(no content)In her work on The Lord of the Rings, Skibniewska only partially adhered to the author's suggestions. She retained the English names of hobbits, whereas she translated some place names into Polish, especially those with clear meanings, thereby introducing the term Śródziemie (Middle-earth) into Polish.

### Tolkien's Opinion

J.R.R. Tolkien, who in one of his less known notes compared Skibniewska to other translators. He wrote: Not all are as humble as the Polish lady.

### Publication History

The three volumes of The Lord of the Rings translated by Skibniewska were published in 1961, 1962, and 1963.(no content)The second edition of The Lord of the Rings was published in 1981, while The Silmarillion came out posthumously in 1985, alongside the second edition of The Hobbit.

Unfortunately, the search results don't provide specific information about Skibniewska's interpretation or translation of the ring in "The Hobbit." The results focus more on her general translation approach, the reception of her work, and her translation choices for proper names and terminology in Tolkien's works.
